review_title: Let me choose how to turn
one_reviews_text:
Ok, first of all this is a great concept for VR,  Actually being in the game and playing Spider Man in the first person view is extremely immersive and the web swinging and mechanics are very fun and done well for the most part. This is also a free program so I am not writing a review to discourage anyone from playing this, it is a cool concept and it is a great demo for the most part. 
 The part that makes me want to uninstall it and never play it again is something that might seem a minor detail, but for me it completely destroys the demo and experience. 
 The way they decided to control rotating your character is with quick instant 90 degree turns. There is no option to shut this off so that you can simply rotate your character, every time you turn you have do a quick, instant 90 degree teleport.  For me personally this turned what started off as a lot of fun into instant loathing. 
First off, I do not like this mechanic in general, I do not like it in VR games period so this is my personal preference. The reason why I do not like it in most games is because it completely destroys the immersion into what I am playin., As human beings when we turn our heads and our body we cannot instantly teleport and rotate our bodies in a 90 degree turn. In this experience/demo it is an extremely terrible design choice because we have to use our stick on the controller to climb walls or run forward so if you are climbing the wall or running sometimes you might accidentaly rotate your character by accidentaly bumping the trigger to the left or to the right and if you do a couple in a row or just wind up at a bad view angle you can lose track of the direction you were going.  Also if you do a quick rotate and you wind up at an angle that is different from the way you want to go you might not be lined up right, you might have the body angled to the left or right of the way you want to be facing. Let me decide how I want my character to turn,terrible design choice.

Also, I also appreciate that there are various accessibility options for those who may not have their VR legs, like vignetting while in motion.  You can definitely turn it all off (the Immersive setting does that for you), but be ready for it - I could see many VR users getting sick from that!

review_title: Super fun, but a couple critiques.
one_reviews_text:
This game is no doubt fun. I really enjoy swiming around the city and feeling like Spiderman, and the combat and racing trials can give you some stuff to do. But, there is a reason I'm giving it a 4 star, because I have a couple of main critique about this game, nothing "bad" though.

The problem I have is with the actual web swinging. It's fun and functional, but the physics feel off. Typically, when you imagine "swinging" from a web or rope, the way it works is that you continue to fall downward until the rope's strength catches you, and your momentum carries you forward in an arc fasion. In this game, however, when you shoot your web and it anchors to a point, like on the side of a building, instead of continuing to fall downward until the web catches you, you instead start to "reel" toward's the anchor point. So, essentially, you can fall, shoot a web to the side of a building, then just hold it and you'll basically "fly" right to where your web landed. Gravity still takes effect, but only somewhat, so when you want to actually webswing, it feels pretty floaty.

The other issue I have, though not as bad as the first, is how you reload your web. To reload, you have to shoot your web out of your sights, like behind your back. At first, I did think this was a pretty neat and fun idea. But, as you get more experienced with swinging around the city, and attempting cooler tricks, you quickly realize how annoying it can get when you want to swing or shoot your web to something off to the side of you, but instead you just reload. I think a very easy alternative, could be a dedicated button to reloading, as right now, all of the face buttons on the controller are just to jump.

I understand, it's a free game, hence why I think it's great for the content it gives you. But, if they decide to actually make a full length paid game out of this concept, I would really like to see them improve the web swinging physics and fix the reloading.

review_title: A Four Star Experience With A Flaw
one_reviews_text:
Another great Spider-Man experience without a doubt, but unfortunately brought down by a web swinging mechanic that pulls you out of the immersion every time you pull the trigger.

There's no denying this is a great and immersive Spider-Man experience that is as close to the feeling of being Spider-Man as we have ever gotten. You can even load up Free Play mode and just swing around the city to your hearts content.

Unfortunately, the oddly implemented web swinging mechanic pulls you out of the experience every time you use it, which is just about the entire time.

For some reason the developers chose to have webs behave sort of like a grappling hook that pulls you toward the webs anchor point while you are swinging, almost eliminating the need to actually swing at all. You can just sort of pull yourself through the air, and the problem with this is, it just feels wrong, looks wrong, and you will probably be thinking that every time you use your web slingers, completely destroying the immersion.

If the grappling web mechanic was needed for gameplay reasons it should have had it's own seperate control, such as pulling the trigger and then pressing the grip button to pull yourself up the web. However changing the core physics of how Spider-Man travels seems to be an overstep on the part of the developers that I think most will not find to be a welcome one.

That issue aside, this demo showing the possibilities of how great a full Spider-Man VR game could be, definitely hits the mark. We get to feel like we are Spider-Man while playing, and if we had some villains, a story, and a more fleshed out city that felt alive, it could be...well....AMAZING!

review_title: Worth it, but some truly sadistic design
one_reviews_text:
Free physics-based swinging video game fans have fantasized about since Spider-Man 2 on PS2, you can experience yourself?! Uh yeah, definitely. 

That said, I was surprised to find this short experience has some of the most devilish, sadistic, and because this is VR, literally physically punishing features in any video game I've played. 

What am I talking about? Well, there are 5 time trials and 5 combat trials (not 1 of each like some reviews suggest) - you just have to scan the area for them, and because draw distance is variable based on computer power, you might think there can only be one (#highlander), but just keep swinging and pulling your arms, stopping, and scanning till you see more.

Combat trials are a piece of cake. In fact (and I totally get this was probably rushed for the movie) enemies spawn in one point and you web 'em up no prob. 

Time trials though?! You know how in most games with this, you miss a checkpoint or time, you just get a button prompt to try again? Oh no, not here - if you miss physically swinging through a checkpoint, THAT checkpoint you missed becomes your "Retry?" window. You have to somehow make it to that.

And oh yeah, you have about 10-15 seconds before it DISAPPEARS and you have to navigate your way back to the starting point.

And oh yeah, THAT BOX FOR SOME REASON BECOMES SMALLER IF YOU WANT TO RETRY. What? I truly don't understand why this included as a feature in this game.

To summarize, you flap your arms wildly to try to get a time trial, and you miss. Wanna try again? Frantically flap your body to try to make it into a smaller box suspended in mid-air, and watch as it disappears in front of you right as you're about to get into it.

Also, there are 25 pins to collect, they're small, there's no info at all about where they might be, and draw distance dictates you won't see them until you're right on them. The scanner does not scan them.

Anyway, great game, your shoulders will hurt like hell, but you'll be jacked.
